- Nintendo’s original business (from 1889) was making hanafuda (flower cards). That was their primary product for many years.

What to look for when examining the cards
1. Printing technique and artwork
   - Early cards may show woodblock printing irregularities, hand-painting, or older lithographic traits (uneven ink, visible brush/print lines, slight misregistration). Modern offset printing is very even.
   - Look for signs of hand finishing (brush strokes, hand-applied pigments).

2. Paper and board
   - Older cards were made from rag or early wood-pulp papers; they feel different (denser, sometimes softer edges) compared with modern pulp or coated stocks.
   - Check the card edges: are they deck-cut by hand or uniform machine-cut? Hand-cut edges are more irregular.
   - Under raking light you can sometimes see chain lines or laid paper texture that indicate 19th/early 20th‑century paper.

3. Maker’s marks, seals, and printing on the box
   - Hanafuda and other Japanese cardmakers often used a publisher’s mark (hanko) or company name in kanji on the cards or box. Ask for clear photos of any kanji/marks.
   - Early Nintendo products sometimes carried the name Nintendo (任天堂) or the maker’s name or seal; but there were many small makers and imitations in that period, so a mark isn’t proof by itself.

4. Packaging and labels
   - Original boxes (if present) should match card age: paper stock, printing method, wear consistent with age.
   - Beware of artificially aged boxes glued to newer cards.

5. Wear, patina and signs of age
   - Genuine century‑old cards show uneven wear, foxing, paper brittleness, insect damage, or repairs. Aging that is uniform across all surfaces or looks contrived (even discoloration, artificially browned edges) can indicate faking.
   - Smell: very old paper has a characteristic musty/old paper smell; chemical or perfume smells can indicate tampering.

6. Inks and pigments
   - Some pigments/dyes were not available until later; bright modern synthetic dyes on an otherwise “old” card are a red flag.

7. Provenance and documentation
   - A clear chain of ownership, receipts, old inventory stamps, or cataloged auction history greatly increases credibility.

Red flags (things that make a claim unlikely)
- The seller offers a Western 52‑card deck branded Nintendo that claims 1890s origin.
- Printing is uniformly modern offset/CMYK while the seller claims hand‑printed 19th‑century manufacture.
- The deck is in improbably pristine condition without convincing provenance.
- The “antique” shows identical wear across every card or obvious chemical/heat aging.

What you should do next
- Ask the seller for high‑resolution photos of: card fronts, backs, edges, box (inside/outside), any kanji or stamps, and closeups of the printing. Include a ruler for scale.
- Request provenance: where and when were they acquired? Any old receipts/labels/auction records?
- Compare to known reference images of antique hanafuda (search museum collections, auction archives, collector sites).
- Get an expert appraisal if it might be valuable: contact an auction house with an Asian antiques department (Sotheby’s, Christie’s, Bonhams) or a specialist in Japanese playing cards/hanafuda. Japanese paper conservators or university East Asian collections can also help.
